text: late on a Monday night and we're at a
crime scene the bodies of three drug
suspects lie under a bridge police say
the men were killed by undercover police
after opening fire during a buy-and-bust
operation but it's unlikely anyone will
find out what really happened philippine
president rodrigo duterte anti-drug
campaign has resulted in nearly 6,000
deaths since he took office crime-scene
investigators usually arrived to the
scene after the press they traced shell
casings on the ground poked around at
the bodies and then invite a local
funeral parlor to take them away that's
it
typically aren't any arrests and little
follow-up information is released the
case is opened and shut right here on
these streets many victims are found
wrapped in tape and plastic often with
signs stuck to their bodies that
identify them as pushers
Ray Carlo East lace was one of those
this is his wake he was 22 years old and
a Duterte supporter his family says he
was innocent didn't use drugs they don't
know who the killer was and they don't
expect to find out and a lot of these
wigs you'll see chicks on the caskets
Ray Carlos family tells me they're there
to peck at the conscience of his killer
jails across the country have filled up
since Duterte took office this is a cell
in a jail in Kaesong city part of Metro
Manila the jail was built to hold 800
inmates a few months after Tudor Tate
took office it reached its peak with
about 4,000 most inmates are drug
suspects it's hot and so densely packed
that inmates need to take shifts
sleeping most expect to wait years for a
trial but if you told me that they
prefer being here then out on the
streets identified as drug suspects and
with a target on their backs
I'm Andrew Glaser with The New York
Times
[Music]
